results:
Based on my search results, I can provide information about the topics mentioned in your query, though I found limited direct connections between The Lord of the Rings and Polish romantic messianism. Let me present what I found:

## Polish Romanticism and Messianism

Polish messianism was a literary-philosophical-religious movement in Polish culture, with its greatest flowering in the 19th century between the November and January uprisings. Literature and messianic philosophy were an important component of Polish romanticism (sometimes they are even identified with it).(no content)In romantic messianism, the suffering of the Polish nation was not a punishment for sins, but an act of salvation for other nations – analogous to the passion of Christ, who through his sacrifice brought redemption to all humanity. This also distinguished Poland as a chosen nation among others.(no content)The movement sought rationalization for the fall of the Polish state, repression after the November Uprising, and their own weakness against the partitioners. They found it in emphasizing their own moral superiority, treating misfortunes and suffering as purifying forces, or interpreting their own fate in terms of biblical redemption of sins. This favored the creation of literary and philosophical works emphasizing the exceptional historical mission of the Polish nation and mythologizing the Polish past.

## Themes of Resistance and Occupation

According to Słowacki, Poland should realize its mission of sacrifice to Europe through active action: fight, uprisings and resistance against the oppressors of freedom.(no content)Romanticism was largely a period of partitions, and therefore also of the coming of age of the first generations of Poles who grew up in the reality of a nation deprived of a sovereign state. Like ancient Israel, the enslaved people awaited prophets who could lead them.

## Lord of the Rings and Historical Context

Regarding Tolkien's work specifically, the search results show some connections to historical context:

The Lord of the Rings trilogy was written in the years 1936-1949. Direct references can be found here both to the times of World War II (Tolkien's son Christopher fought in it), as well as to all kinds of totalitarianisms, such as fascism and communism. These are hidden under the mask of Tolkien's Morgoth (fallen angel, creator of evil) and his most faithful and powerful servant, Sauron.(no content)The One Ring was also to be an allegory of powerful force that fell into unauthorized hands, unable to use it well, such as the atomic bomb (The Lord of the Rings was written mainly in the 1940s).

## Polish Reception of Tolkien

The search results indicate there has been scholarly interest in Polish reception of Tolkien's works, with three main streams of Polish research on Tolkien's works documented in academic studies, though the specific content connecting his work to Polish romantic messianism wasn't directly accessible in the search results.

While I found extensive material on Polish romantic messianism and its themes of chosen nation, suffering, resistance against occupation, and redemption, I was unable to find specific scholarly sources that directly analyze The Lord of the Rings through the lens of Polish romantic history and messianic themes. The cultural parallels you're asking about would likely require access to specialized academic publications that weren't fully available in my search results.
